title: COFFEE What Type of Coffee Machine do you have?
content:
What type of coffee machine do you have in your office? Like it? How’s the coffee taste? We’ve got a Bunn Auto Drip one and no matter what we put through it it taste less than desirable.

I use a [Philips Coffee Gourmet](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/www.aktie-online.nl/images/843410.jpg) machine, because it actually boils the water before it touches the coffee grind. A lot of coffee machines don’t do that, they just make it warm-ish. This is for very good coffee. If I want a quick, but still fairly good coffee, I use a [Philips Senseo](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/www.dejuistekeus.nl/images/philips_hdsenseotitanium.jpg) machine with coffee-pads.  
But as long as the machine boils the water, the beans or grind are important as well.

I knew Stefan would chime in. He is ritualistic about his espresso. Being raised in Utah I wasn’t exposed to much coffee. Stefan introduced me to espresso when I worked in his office a few years ago, and now that our office has an espresso machine I don’t ever drink drip coffee. We got this [Gaggia](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/www.coffeegeek.com/reviews/consumer/gaggia_espresso) and have been happy with it. It’s rated at CoffeeGeek as the best espresso maker under $300.

Surprisingly not bad either although it’s no “real espresso” (but there is “crema”, produced by a special valve):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/bialetti_brikka_3668.jpg)

But the coffee grinder is really essential. And of course the coffee, which I think has to be tested with the machine. There are huge differences how the same coffee tastes when brewed with a different machine. With Bialetti Brikka e.g. 100% Arabica coffee is too subtle. And the coffee shouldn’t be too old. At the moment I use an indonesian mixture called “sulawesi kalossi”, freshly roasted by the coffee bar in town, mhm ...

I think those Bialetti things do make ’real espresso’?  
I have used those every now and then as well, nice coffee.

It’s only from a purist’s view and it’s based on the steam developed while brewing coffee:  
“Common” Bialettis produce a beverage called “mokka”, with Brikka it’s a bit different because of the special valve. Here the steam is accumulating until the vapor pressure has reached 6 bar. Big espresso machines generally reach more (ca. 10) bar, which results in a better “crema”.  
To complicate things even more: oriental coffee brewed in a little pitcher (boiled up 3 times, with lots of sugar and a little cardamom, no accumulating of steam) is also called mokka.

I keep it as simple as possible and use a Melitta one-cup drip cone. It does nothing special and doesn’t make the best coffee around, but it takes about a second to empty and I can run it through the dishwasher.

FWIW, Keuring machines may be quick and easy office coffee makers, but they produce some of the most pathetic coffee I have ever tasted.

Chris: _What do you French Press users do about the “silt” that is left in the coffee? I personally don’t like it, have tried pouring it through a filter, which takes way too much time._

For French press coffee, you want a very coarse grind to prevent small bits of coffee grounds getting through the press filter. Blade grinders are ideal for this (in fact, it’s the only thing they’re good for: they don’t grind nearly fine enough for espresso or moka (e.g. Turkish coffee)). I give one short burst on a blade grinder for each spoonful of coffee beans (usually five for a full-size pot): that breaks the coffee up enough to release the flavour, but not enough to produce much ’silt’. There will always be a small amount of powder, no matter how coarse the grind, but that shouldn’t bother you.

Mind you, I like Turkish coffee, so finding a small mudslide in the bottom of my cup isn’t an issue.

Christopher, yes it’s a Reg Barber. My Rancilio is at home as well. At the office we have an Isomac Giada. I like them both, but my favourite is the Rancilio.

At home I have a pretty crappy drip machine with a hotplate that will burn the coffee if you leave it in the pot for too long. But then, I also use Maxwell House in it, so it doesn’t much matter.

My other coffee-makers are: one of those tiny stove top things — but now that I no longer have a gas stove it’s not so great — and a Bodum French press which I really like, but am terribly lazy about cleaning out afterwards. In the Bodum I use good coffee. My more recent forays have been “Kick Ass” made by Kicking Horse, which is fair trade.

I like my coffee overly strong, and I have no problem with the silt. If it’s not there I sorta think something’s missing. My inlaws make incredibly weak (coloured water) coffee. Something like half a spoon of coffee for every two cups. Ew. I always have to remember when they visit to make it “their way”. When they’re over I make two pots — the maxwell house crap and my bodum.

At work, I have no desk space, but I tried one of those one cup drip machines. Problem was it splattered, and made such a mess. Communal coffee pots just don’t work in our office — I even have problems even keeping a small carton of cream in the fridge. It either spoils or gets finished by other people (thieves!). So it’s downstairs to Timmy’s Ho for me, twice a day. I’ve actually grown to like it. Somehow it fits the work environment just so well. Every once in a while I get a paper cup that is leaking at the seam, and it makes the morning all the more enjoyable. ;)

Regarding the aeropress—yes, I have one and it’s excellent. I’d highly recommend it, though it takes some calibration before you get the timing and proportions right. But once you get your routine, it makes great Moka-type espresso. I sometimes dilute it to make Americano.

I used to use a [Chemex manual drip coffeemaker](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/chemexcoffeemaker.com/). Now I just use the Aeropress (and a French press when I’m in the mood for unfiltered coffee). Although the Chemex makes better drip coffee than any automatic drip machine I’ve had, it’s still drip coffee. I prefer a small, strong cup of coffee (or espresso) to a weak pitcher of drip coffee.

Fresh-roasted beans make a huge difference, as long as you grind them just before you make the coffee. There’s no comparison between beans roasted yesterday and beans roasted 6 months ago (that “expire” in another year). Check with a local independent coffee shop: they probably buy their beans from someone local.

_Mind you, I like Turkish coffee, so finding a small mudslide in the bottom of my cup isn’t an issue._

Indeed, just as with Greek coffee, it’s a requirement. The variety with cardomom is also a refreshing change of pace...

I’ve had a Melita one-serve drip for years, which my sweetie uses — I gave up coffee years ago.

Tea is my non-alco bev of choice: preferably minty.

Oldnick: _Indeed, just as with Greek coffee, it’s a requirement._

As I understand (from Greek friends), prior to the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in the 1970s  
even the Greek called this drink ’Turkish coffee’.

The addition of cardomom is typically Arabic: you can buy Arabic blends with the cardomom already added. I’ve noticed that the Arabic, Bosnian and Romanian varieties tend to be a darker roast. I prefer the Turkish and Greek brands, which are a medium roast and don’t require as much sugar.

<cite>But then, I also use Maxwell House in it...</cite>

I once worked in an office with dozens of people from the deep south, where everyone drinks Maxwell House like water. The smell was unbearable—a friend and I had to stash our own coffee maker in her cubicle and stay out of the kitchen.

My grandmother was from Greece and came to this country in about 1916. She called it Turkish coffee.

Braun Coffeemaker  
(I have the Aromaster KF420 which they don’t make any more. It brews great coffee and is an ergonomic marvel.) Get an inexpensive 10 cup: it’s better to brew fresh coffee more often than to drink old muddy coffee. As with any coffeemaker, turn it off after it finishes brewing, unless you want your coffee cooked and bitter. Reheat leftover cups in a microwave. New Braun 10 cup model KF510 in white or black, $30 at [Amazon (White only)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/%252Bhttp%25253A%25252F%25252Fwww.amazon.com%25252FBraun-KF510-WH-AromaDeluxe-10-Cup-Coffeemaker%25252Fdp%25252FB00006JL0A)with free shipping. ($35-50 elsewhere)

Krups 203 Coffee Grinder (in white or black); about $20  
Works great; other grinders make a mess.

Try Kenya AA (“excellent body, heady aroma, very little bitterness”) or Ethiopian Yirgacheffe (“distinctive floral bouquet, rich body, a pleasingly fragrant aroma, with a smooth mellowness”) if you haven’t already. Best coffee prices online are at [California Coffee Roasters.](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322020934/http:/www.freshcoffee.net/) A five pound bag is $30 + shipping.
